dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: I'd love to hear about the Great Storm, Lars.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, the Great Storm. It was back in '63, a night I'll never forget. I was just a young lad, about 15, working on my father's boat. The sky turned a shade of gray I had never seen before. We were out in the North Sea, and the waves... they were monstrous. I remember gripping onto the rigging for dear life, praying we'd make it back to shore. The wind howled like a banshee, and there was this chill in the air that went straight to your bones. My father was a tough man, but even he looked worried.

sentence_annotations.text: Ah, the Great Storm. It was back in '63, a night I'll never forget.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_turns.text: That must have been hard, gripping onto the rigging like that at such a young age. It sounds like you had quite the experience with the sea early on. So when did things change for you, when did you decide to buy your own boat?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Subject
dialogue_turns.text: Well, after surviving that storm, I knew the sea was where I belonged, despite the danger. You see, it was around the late '70s, and I had saved up every penny I could get my hands on from years of working alongside my father. I was in my thirties when I finally got enough to buy my own boat. It wasn't much, just a small trawler, but it was mine. The feeling of independence was exhilarating. I named her 'The Seawind' and I was determined to make a living off the waters I had grown to respect and love.
